Absolute_Carve-Outs.answer: changes in general economic, financial market, regulatory, business, financial, political, geopolitical, credit or capital market conditions, including interest or exchange rates, tariffs and trade wars; general changes or developments in any of the industries or markets in which such Person or any of its Subsidiaries operate; adoption, implementation, repeal, modification or amendment of any applicable Laws; changes in GAAP; acts of war (whether or not declared), hostilities, military actions or acts of terrorism, cyberterrorism (to the extent not specifically targeting such Person), or any escalation or worsening of the foregoing, weather related events, fires, natural disasters, epidemics, pandemics, plagues or other outbreaks of illness or disease or public health events (including COVID-19) or any other acts of God

Absolute_Carve-Outs.reason: The carve-out is explicitly listed within the definition of Material Adverse Effect, indicating it modifies this definition.

The financing commitments are in place, and there is mention of internal cash and amounts available to be drawn on the Parent Credit Facilities to consummate the Merger.

Antitrust_Commitment.answer: The initial outside date for the transaction is 11:59 p.m. (New York City time) on December 13, 2018. The outside date can be extended to June 13, 2019, and further to December 13, 2019, if certain conditions related to Required Governmental Consents are not met. Additionally, if a Governmental Entity issues an Order that is not final and non-appealable, the outside date can be extended by six months, or until two business days after the Order becomes final and non-appealable, or until the date the Subsequent Merger is required to occur.
categories_used: Conditions to Closing  >  General and Mutual Conditions

Antitrust_Commitment.answer: The termination date for the transaction can be extended under the following conditions: If any of the Required Governmental Consents have not been obtained by the Initial Termination Date of December 13, 2018, and all other conditions have been satisfied or waived, the date can be extended to June 13, 2019. If the Required Governmental Consents are still not obtained by the First Extended Termination Date, it can be further extended to December 13, 2019. Additionally, if a Governmental Entity has issued an Order that is not final and non-appealable, the termination date can be extended by six months, two business days after the Subsequent Merger is required to occur, or until the Order becomes final and non-appealable, whichever is earliest.
Antitrust_Commitment.reason: The conditions for extending the termination date are explicitly outlined in the provided excerpts, detailing specific dates and conditions under which extensions are granted.
categories_used: Conditions to Closing  >  General and Mutual Conditions

Additionally, there are provisions for extending the Termination Date if certain regulatory approvals are not obtained. Termination fees are also mentioned in the context of certain breaches or failures to perform.

Antitrust_Commitment.answer: Parent, Merger Sub, and Parent's Subsidiaries are committed to taking all necessary actions to eliminate impediments under any Antitrust Law, including Remedy Actions such as selling, divesting, holding separate, leasing, licensing, transferring, or otherwise restricting assets or businesses. However, they are not required to take Remedy Actions with respect to businesses and products of the Company and its Subsidiaries that generated net sales in excess of $140,000,000 during the Company's 2024 fiscal year. Remedy Actions are also conditioned upon the consummation of the transactions.
Antitrust_Commitment.reason: The agreement specifies obligations to take actions necessary to obtain antitrust approvals, including Remedy Actions, with certain financial thresholds and conditions.

Best_Efforts.answer: In the event of a failure to perform obligations under the agreement, the parties are entitled to remedies such as injunctions, specific performance, and other equitable relief to prevent breaches and enforce the terms of the agreement. This is in addition to any other remedies available at law or in equity. Termination rights and liability for damages are also outlined, particularly in cases of intentional breach or fraud.
Best_Efforts.reason: The agreement specifies that irreparable damage would occur if provisions are not performed, and monetary damages would not be adequate. Therefore, equitable remedies like injunctions and specific performance are available, as well as termination rights and liability for damages in certain cases.

Best_Efforts.answer: (i) making HSR or regulatory filings, (ii) obtaining governmental or third-party consents, (iii) defending litigation, (iv) satisfying conditions to closing, (v) cooperating with the other party

Best_Efforts.answer: The scope of best efforts includes using reasonable best efforts to consummate the transactions, obtain necessary consents and approvals, make required filings, defend against legal challenges, and execute additional necessary instruments, among other actions, as outlined in Section 5.4(a).
Best_Efforts.reason: The language in Section 5.4(a) explicitly outlines the scope of best efforts required by the parties, including specific actions to be taken to facilitate the consummation of the transactions.

Breach_Monitoring_and_Ongoing_Operations.answer: The representations and warranties must remain accurate at the time of closing. The materiality or knowledge qualifiers are as follows: (i) certain specified representations and warranties must be true and correct in all respects, except for de minimis inaccuracies; (ii) fundamental representations must be true and correct in all material respects, without giving effect to any materiality or 'Material Adverse Effect' qualifications; and (iii) other representations and warranties must be true and correct, except where the failure to be true and correct has not had, and would not reasonably be expected to have, a Material Adverse Effect.
Breach_Monitoring_and_Ongoing_Operations.reason: The conditions to the obligations to effect the merger include requirements for the accuracy of representations and warranties at closing, with specific materiality qualifiers outlined.
categories_used: Conditions to Closing  >  General and Mutual Conditions

Breach_Monitoring_and_Ongoing_Operations.reason: Section 7.1(c)(i) and Section 7.1(d)(i) both specify a 30 calendar day period for curing a breach after delivery of written notice, implying a cure period for breaches.

Breach_Monitoring_and_Ongoing_Operations.answer: The agreement allows a party to terminate due to the other party's breach of representations, warranties, or covenants if such breach would result in the failure of a condition to closing and is not capable of being cured by the Termination Date or is not cured within 30 calendar days following written notice of such breach. The right to terminate requires notice and failure to cure.
Breach_Monitoring_and_Ongoing_Operations.reason: The agreement specifies conditions under which a party can terminate due to a breach, including the requirement for notice and a 30-day cure period, which is a standard provision in M&A agreements.

Breach_Monitoring_and_Ongoing_Operations.answer: Material interim changes requiring disclosure under covenants or access rights should be treated as supplemental disclosure obligations.
Breach_Monitoring_and_Ongoing_Operations.reason: The language in Section 5.07(c) regarding prompt notice of changes that could result in a Material Adverse Effect implies a supplemental disclosure obligation for material interim changes.

Breach_Monitoring_and_Ongoing_Operations.answer: The Buyer is granted reasonable access to the Target's personnel, properties, books, and records during normal business hours and upon reasonable notice, from the date of the Agreement to the Effective Time. This access is for purposes including reviewing the performance and operation of the Company. The Buyer is also entitled to receive information concerning the business, properties, and personnel of the Company as reasonably requested. These provisions imply monitoring rights to ensure the Target continues operating in the ordinary course and complies with covenants.
Breach_Monitoring_and_Ongoing_Operations.reason: The language in Sections 5.5 and 5.07 provides the Buyer with access to information and personnel, which implies monitoring rights to ensure compliance with covenants and ordinary course operations.

Clean_Room_Agreement.reason: The document discusses data protection and IT assets, implying that confidential business information is shared, even though a detailed list is not provided.
The agreement mentions that access is afforded to Parent's Representatives, which includes advisors, and requires confidentiality agreements, implying external handling.

The section on Access to Information; Confidentiality implies that the clean room data is used for preparing for and effecting the transactions, transition and integration planning, and reviewing the performance and operation of the Company, which are standard due diligence activities.
The termination clause in Section 7.2 mentions that the Confidentiality Agreement survives termination, which typically includes obligations to return or destroy confidential information.
The clean room obligations are likely tied to due diligence activities, which typically conclude at the closing of the transaction.
The Clean Room Agreement is part of the entire agreement along with the Confidentiality Agreement, as indicated in Section 8.8 and Section 8.07, suggesting a supplementary relationship.
The Confidentiality Agreement, which is likely related to clean room access, is dated January 23, 2025, and no other specific start date for clean room access is provided.

Clean_Room_Agreement.answer: Until the earlier of the Effective Time or termination of the Agreement
Clean_Room_Agreement.reason: The termination clauses and the survival of covenants imply that access ends at the Effective Time or upon termination of the Agreement.

Closing.answer: as soon as reasonably practicable, and in no event later than the third business day, following the day on which the last to be satisfied or waived of each of the conditions set forth in Article VI shall have been satisfied or waived

Closing.answer: The Company shall use reasonable best efforts to deliver to Parent, at least three (3) Business Days prior to the Closing Date, a draft of, and on or prior to the Closing Date, an executed copy of, a customary payoff letter from the administrative agent under the Existing Company Credit Agreement setting forth the amount required to pay off in full on the Closing Date the Indebtedness and other obligations outstanding under the Existing Company Credit Agreement and all other related loan documents, setting forth the wire transfer instructions for the payment of the Payoff Amount, and releasing all Liens securing such Indebtedness and other obligations and all guarantees of such Indebtedness, and terminating the Existing Company Credit Agreement and all other related loan documents, in each case, automatically upon receipt of the Payoff Amount.
categories_used: The Merger  >  Effective Time & Closing Process

Closing.answer: The Acquirer (or Parent) is obligated to perform several actions at or prior to Closing, including: (1) ensuring that the shares of Parent Common Stock issuable to the Company stockholders pursuant to the Initial Merger are authorized for listing on the NYSE upon official notice of issuance; (2) ensuring that the shares of SpinCo Common Stock issuable to the holders of the Shares pursuant to the Distribution are authorized for listing on the Nasdaq upon official notice of issuance; (3) obtaining all necessary Governmental Consents, including those under the HSR Act and from the FCC; (4) ensuring the effectiveness of the Registration Statements under the Securities Act and the Exchange Act; (5) ensuring that Merger Sub performs its obligations under the Agreement and does not conduct any business outside of its obligations related to the Agreement; and (6) providing a certificate signed by an executive officer of Parent certifying the truth and correctness of representations and warranties and the performance of obligations. These obligations are implied through the conditions set forth in the agreement and the responsibilities outlined for the Parent and Merger Sub.

Closing.answer: The Company is required to deliver documents, filings, and notices for the termination of the Existing Company Credit Agreement and related loan documents, including the release of all Liens, on or prior to the Closing. Additionally, there are obligations related to the Debt Offers and Debt Payoff that are conditioned on the occurrence of the Closing. These obligations imply post-closing deliverables related to the payoff and termination of certain financial agreements.
Closing.reason: The language in Section 5.13 and Section 5.16 implies that certain documents and actions related to debt payoff and termination are required to be completed in connection with the Closing, suggesting post-closing deliverables.

Closing.answer: Prior to the Effective Time, upon Parent's request, the Company shall use commercially reasonable efforts to cause any director of the Company to resign as a director effective as of the Effective Time. Additionally, Jesse Singh, Gary Hendrickson, and Howard Heckes are to be appointed to the Parent Board as directors upon the Effective Time.
Closing.reason: The document specifies that directors of the Company may be requested to resign at the Effective Time and that specific individuals are to be appointed to the Parent Board at the Effective Time.

Closing.answer: At or substantially concurrently with the Effective Time, Parent shall deposit or cause to be deposited with the Exchange Agent, for exchange in accordance with this Article II through the Exchange Agent, (i) uncertificated book-entry shares representing the full number of whole Parent Shares issuable pursuant to Section 2.1(a)(ii) in exchange for outstanding shares of Company Common Stock and (ii) cash in an aggregate amount necessary to pay the Cash Consideration portion of the Merger Consideration.

categories_used: Conditions to Closing  >  General and Mutual Conditions

Closing.answer: The shares of Parent Common Stock to be issued in the Initial Merger will be approved for listing on the NYSE, and the shares of SpinCo Common Stock to be distributed in the Distribution will be approved for listing on Nasdaq. The Company will take actions to delist its shares from Nasdaq and NYSE and deregister under the Exchange Act as soon as possible following the Effective Time.

Each of Parent, the Company, the Surviving Corporation and the Exchange Agent shall be entitled to deduct and withhold, or cause to be deducted and withheld, from any amounts otherwise payable pursuant to this Agreement to any Person such amounts as are required to be deducted and withheld with respect to the making of such payment under the Code or any provision of applicable Tax Law. To the extent that amounts are so deducted or withheld and timely paid over to the relevant Governmental Authority, such deducted or withheld amounts shall be treated for all purposes of this Agreement as having been paid to the Person in respect of which such deduction or withholding was made.

Company_Material_Adverse_Change.answer: Material Adverse Effect shall mean, with respect to Parent or the Company, any event, circumstance, occurrence, effect, fact, development or change that, individually or in the aggregate, has a material adverse effect on the business, financial condition or results of operations of such Person and its Subsidiaries, taken as a whole; provided that none of the following (or the results thereof) shall constitute or be taken into account in determining whether a Material Adverse Effect shall have occurred: (i) changes in general economic, financial market, regulatory, business, financial, political, geopolitical, credit or capital market conditions, including interest or exchange rates, tariffs and trade wars; (ii) general changes or developments in any of the industries or markets in which such Person or any of its Subsidiaries operate; (iii) (A) adoption, implementation, repeal, modification or amendment of any applicable Laws or (B) changes in GAAP, or in the case of each of clause (A) and (B), any proposal therefor or change in interpretations or enforcement thereof; (iv) any change in the price or trading volume of such Person's securities or other financial instruments or change in such Person's credit rating, in and of itself (provided that the facts or occurrences giving rise to or contributing to such change that are not otherwise excluded from the definition of "Material Adverse Effect" may constitute or be taken into account in determining whether a Material Adverse Effect has occurred); (v) any failure by such Person to meet its internal or published projections, budgets, plans or forecasts of its revenues, earnings or other financial performance or results of operation or any published analyst or other third-party estimates or expectations of such Person's revenue, earnings or other financial performance or results of operations for any period, in and of itself (provided that the facts or occurrences giving rise to or contributing to such failure that are not otherwise excluded from the definition of "Material Adverse Effect" may constitute or be taken into account in determining whether a Material Adverse Effect has occurred); (vi) acts of war (whether or not declared), hostilities, military actions or acts of terrorism, cyberterrorism (to the extent not specifically targeting such Person), or any escalation or worsening of the foregoing, weather related events, fires, natural disasters, epidemics, pandemics, plagues or other outbreaks of illness or disease or public health events (including COVID-19) or any other acts of God; (vii) any action taken or (to the extent the relevant action is expressly permitted by the terms of this Agreement) not taken at the express written request of the Company (in the case of Parent) or Parent (in the case of the Company) after the date of this Agreement; (viii) the identity of Company (in the case of Parent) or Parent (in the case of the Company) and, other than with respect to a representation or warranty contained in this Agreement to the extent that the purpose of such representation or warranty is to address the consequences resulting from the execution and delivery of this Agreement or the consummation of the Merger or the performance of obligations under this Agreement, the execution of this Agreement, the public announcement, pendency or consummation of the Merger or the other transactions contemplated by this Agreement (including, to the extent resulting from the foregoing, any effect on any of such Persons or any of its Subsidiaries relationships with their respective customers, suppliers or employees); or (ix) any matter disclosed against a representation or warranty set forth in Article III in the Company Disclosure Letter (as it relates to the Company) or Article IV in the Parent Disclosure Letter in (as it relates to Parent); provided, further, that, the exceptions in clauses (i) through (iii) and (vi) shall not apply to the extent the events, circumstances, occurrences, effects, facts, developments or changes set forth in such clauses have a disproportionate impact on such Person and its Subsidiaries, taken as a whole, relative to the other participants in the industries in which such Person and its Subsidiaries operate.

Company_Material_Adverse_Change.answer: changes in general economic, financial market, regulatory, business, financial, political, geopolitical, credit or capital market conditions, including interest or exchange rates, tariffs and trade wars; general changes or developments in any of the industries or markets in which such Person or any of its Subsidiaries operate; adoption, implementation, repeal, modification or amendment of any applicable Laws or changes in GAAP; any change in the price or trading volume of such Person's securities or other financial instruments or change in such Person's credit rating; any failure by such Person to meet its internal or published projections, budgets, plans or forecasts of its revenues, earnings or other financial performance or results of operation; acts of war (whether or not declared), hostilities, military actions or acts of terrorism, cyberterrorism (to the extent not specifically targeting such Person), or any escalation or worsening of the foregoing, weather related events, fires, natural disasters, epidemics, pandemics, plagues or other outbreaks of illness or disease or public health events (including COVID-19) or any other acts of God; any action taken or not taken at the express written request of the Company or Parent; the identity of Company or Parent and the execution of this Agreement, the public announcement, pendency or consummation of the Merger or the other transactions contemplated by this Agreement; any matter disclosed against a representation or warranty set forth in Article III in the Company Disclosure Letter or Article IV in the Parent Disclosure Letter

Complete_Effects_on_Capital_Stock.answer: Each share of Company Common Stock issued and outstanding immediately prior to the Effective Time shall be automatically canceled and converted into the right to receive $26.45 per share in cash and a number of Parent Shares equal to the Exchange Ratio. Each share of common stock of Merger Sub shall be converted into one newly issued share of common stock of the Surviving Corporation. Excluded Shares and Dissenting Shares are canceled without consideration. Adjustments may occur for stock splits or similar events.
categories_used: The Merger  >  Mechanics and Statutory Effects

Complete_Effects_on_Capital_Stock.answer: Each share of Company Common Stock issued and outstanding immediately prior to the Effective Time (other than Canceled Shares and Dissenting Shares) shall be automatically canceled and converted into the right to receive the Merger Consideration, which includes cash and Parent Shares.
categories_used: The Merger  >  Mechanics and Statutory Effects
The Merger  >  Mechanics and Statutory Effects

Complete_Effects_on_Capital_Stock.answer: Vested and unvested options are treated as follows: Company Performance Stock Units (PSUs) and Company Restricted Stock Units (RSUs) are converted into Parent restricted stock units, maintaining the same terms and conditions, except that PSUs will only have service-based vesting conditions post-conversion. Company RSUs granted to non-employee board members will vest fully and be canceled in exchange for the Merger Consideration. Other Company RSUs and PSUs will be assumed by Parent and converted into time-based restricted stock units of Parent and cash awards, with performance-based conditions removed. Company Stock Options that are vested, or granted to non-employees or former employees, will be canceled for the Merger Consideration Value. Unvested options will be assumed by Parent and converted into options to purchase Parent Shares. Double trigger vesting applies to certain units within two years post-closing.
Complete_Effects_on_Capital_Stock.reason: The treatment of options is detailed across multiple sections, specifying conversion, assumption, and vesting conditions, which are standard in M&A agreements.
categories_used: The Merger  >  Mechanics and Statutory Effects

Complete_Effects_on_Capital_Stock.answer: The voting rights of the Company's shares will be indirectly affected as all shares of Company Common Stock will be canceled and converted into the right to receive cash and Parent Shares. This implies a change in voting rights as the Company's shares will cease to exist, and the holders will instead have voting rights in Parent Shares.
Complete_Effects_on_Capital_Stock.reason: The cancellation and conversion of Company Common Stock into Parent Shares implies a change in voting rights, as the original shares will no longer exist, and the holders will now have voting rights in the Parent entity.

Complete_Effects_on_Capital_Stock.answer: In lieu of fractional shares, each record holder of Company Common Stock who would otherwise be entitled to such fractional shares shall be entitled to an amount in cash, without interest, rounded down to the nearest cent, equal to the product of the fractional share interest and the Parent Share Price.
categories_used: The Merger  >  Mechanics and Statutory Effects

Complete_Effects_on_Capital_Stock.answer: The exchange ratio for the merger consideration per share is defined as the Exchange Ratio, which is 1.0340. Additionally, each share of Company Common Stock is entitled to receive $26.45 per share in cash. The Exchange Ratio may be adjusted based on certain conditions such as changes in the number of shares due to reclassification, recapitalization, or stock splits. Different ratios apply to different classes of stock, such as Class A and Class B Common Stock, which are exchanged for Parent Common Stock at the Exchange Ratio. The Equity Award Exchange Ratio is calculated as the sum of the quotient of the Cash Consideration divided by the Parent Share Price and the Exchange Ratio.
categories_used: The Merger  >  Mechanics and Statutory Effects

Complete_Effects_on_Capital_Stock.answer: The post-merger capitalization table is not explicitly provided, but it can be inferred that each share of Company Common Stock will be converted into the right to receive $26.45 in cash and a number of Parent Shares equal to the Exchange Ratio. The Exchange Ratio is defined as the Base Exchange Ratio of 0.2745 plus an adjustment based on the Equity Adjustment Amount. The authorized share capital of Parent consists of 2,000,000,000 Parent Shares, with 429,818,781 issued and outstanding as of the Parent Capitalization Date. The authorized capital stock of the Company consists of 1,100,000,000 shares of Company Common Stock, with 143,847,919 shares issued and outstanding as of the Company Capitalization Date. The final capitalization will depend on the Exchange Ratio and any adjustments due to changes in the number of shares or securities convertible into shares prior to the merger.
Complete_Effects_on_Capital_Stock.reason: The merger consideration and exchange ratio are clearly defined, and the current capitalization figures for both the Parent and the Company are provided, allowing for a reasonable inference of the post-merger capitalization structure.
categories_used: The Merger  >  Post-Closing Board and Management

Complete_Effects_on_Capital_Stock.answer: The conversion of securities is subject to several conditions: (a) obtaining the Company Stockholder Approval, (b) approval for listing of the Parent Share Issuance on the NYSE, (c) effectiveness of the Form F-4 under the Securities Act without any stop order, (d) expiration or early termination of any applicable waiting period under the HSR Act, and (e) no governmental order or law prohibiting the consummation of the Merger. Additionally, adjustments to stock prices due to changes in the number of shares or securities convertible into shares may also affect the conversion process.
Complete_Effects_on_Capital_Stock.reason: The conditions for conversion are implied through the conditions to consummate the merger and adjustments to prevent dilution, which are standard prerequisites for conversion in M&A agreements.
categories_used: The Merger  >  Mechanics and Statutory Effects

Complete_Effects_on_Capital_Stock.answer: Dissenting shares are an explicit exception where stockholders are treated differently, as they are not converted into the right to receive the Merger Consideration but are entitled to receive consideration as determined under Section 262 of the DGCL. Additionally, holders of Company Performance Stock Units and Company Restricted Stock Units receive special treatment as their awards are converted into Parent restricted stock units with specific terms. Directors and executives may also receive special treatment through the conversion of their equity awards, which are subject to 'double trigger' vesting provisions.
Complete_Effects_on_Capital_Stock.reason: The agreement explicitly mentions dissenting shares and the conversion of equity awards for directors and executives, indicating special treatment for these groups.

Confidentiality_Agreement.reason: The Confidentiality Agreement is explicitly stated to survive the termination of the Agreement in Section 8.01, which implies it also survives the consummation of the Mergers.

Confidentiality_Agreement.answer: injunctive relief, specific performance, other equitable relief

Covenants.answer: The Company shall afford reasonable access to Parent's Representatives, during normal business hours and upon reasonable notice, to the personnel, advisors, properties, books and records of the Company and its Subsidiaries, and furnish all information concerning the business, properties and personnel of the Company and its Subsidiaries as may reasonably be requested for the Intended Purpose.
Covenants.reason: The covenant in Section 5.5 explicitly requires the Company to provide reasonable access to facilities, personnel, contracts, and financial data to the Parent's Representatives for the Intended Purpose.
categories_used: Financing Provisions  >  Auditor Access or Coordination
Conditions to Closing  >  General and Mutual Conditions
The Merger  >  Effective Time & Closing Process

Covenants.answer: The Company and Parent shall cooperate with each other and use their reasonable best efforts to prepare and file as promptly as reasonably practicable all necessary notices, reports, and other filings required under the HSR Act or any Foreign Competition Laws to obtain all necessary consents, registrations, approvals, permits, expirations of waiting periods, and authorizations from any Governmental Entity to consummate the Mergers or any of the other Transactions.
categories_used: Conditions to Closing  >  General and Mutual Conditions

Covenants.answer: The initial press release with respect to the Transactions shall be a joint press release and thereafter the Company and Parent shall consult with each other prior to issuing or making, and provide each other the opportunity to review and comment on, any press releases or other public announcements with respect to the Transactions, except as may be required by applicable Law or by obligations pursuant to any listing agreement with or rules of any national securities exchange.

The Company shall, as soon as reasonably practicable following the effectiveness of the Form F-4, duly call, give notice of, convene and hold a meeting of its stockholders for the purpose of seeking the Company Stockholder Approval.

Parent shall, and shall cause its Subsidiaries (including the Borrower) to, use reasonable best efforts to take, or cause to be taken, all actions, and to do, or cause to be done, all things reasonably necessary to consummate the Financing in an amount sufficient, together with cash on hand and amounts available to be drawn on the Parent Credit Facilities, to consummate the Merger and the other transactions contemplated hereby no later than the Closing, including, to the extent necessary to consummate the Merger and such other transactions, using reasonable best efforts to (i) (A) maintain in effect the Debt Letters and in all material respects comply with all of their respective obligations thereunder and (B) negotiate, enter into and deliver definitive agreements with respect to the Financing reflecting the terms contained in the Debt Letters (or with other terms agreed by Parent and the Financing Parties, subject to the restrictions on amendments of the Debt Letters set forth below), so that such agreements are in effect no later than the Closing, and (ii) satisfy on a timely basis all the conditions to the Financing and the definitive agreements related thereto that are in Parent's (or its Subsidiaries' (including the Borrower's)) control.

Subject to applicable Law, the Company shall give prompt notice to Parent, and Parent shall give prompt notice to the Company, of (a) the occurrence or non-occurrence of any event whose occurrence or non-occurrence, as the case may be, would reasonably be expected to cause, in the case of the Company, any condition set forth in Section 6.2 not to be satisfied, or in the case of Parent, any condition set forth in Section 6.3 not to be satisfied, at any time from the date of this Agreement to the Effective Time, (b) any notice or other communication received by such party from any Governmental Authority in connection with this Agreement, the Merger or the other transactions contemplated by this Agreement, or from any Person alleging that the consent of such Person is or may be required in connection with the Merger or the other transactions contemplated by this Agreement, if the subject matter of such notice or other communication or the failure of such party to obtain such consent would reasonably be expected to be material to the Company, the Surviving Corporation or Parent and (c) any claims, investigations or Proceedings commenced or, to such party's Knowledge, threatened in writing against, relating to or involving or otherwise affecting such party (including its board of directors) or any of its Subsidiaries that relate to this Agreement, the Merger or the other transactions contemplated by this Agreement.

Dividends.reason: Section 5.2(e) explicitly states that Parent shall not declare, authorize, make or pay any dividend or other distribution with respect to its capital stock or other equity interests before the merger closes.

Financing Provisions  >  Accounting Principles for Adjustments
Financing Provisions  >  Accounting Principles for Adjustments

Dividends.answer: The agreement includes a coordination clause in Section 5.18 that requires the Company to coordinate with Parent regarding the declaration, setting of record dates, and payment dates of cash dividends on Shares. This coordination is intended to prevent holders of Shares from receiving regular dividends on both Shares and Parent Common Stock for the same portion of any calendar year or from failing to receive a regular dividend on either Shares or Parent Common Stock for a portion of any calendar year for which a regular dividend would have otherwise been paid.
Dividends.reason: The coordination clause in Section 5.18 implies protection against value erosion due to dividends by ensuring that dividends are not duplicated or missed during the transition period.
categories_used: Financing Provisions  >  Accounting Principles for Adjustments
Conditions to Closing  >  General and Mutual Conditions

Financing.answer: Debt financing from Bank of America, N.A. and Jeffries Finance LLC

categories_used: Conditions to Closing  >  General and Mutual Conditions

Financing.answer: In the event that funds in the amounts set forth in the Debt Letters, or any portion thereof, become unavailable, Parent shall use reasonable best efforts to obtain substitute financing on terms and conditions that are not materially less favorable to Parent than the terms and conditions set forth in the Debt Letters, taking into account any 'market flex' provisions.

The Company is obligated to provide reasonable cooperation in connection with the Financing, including furnishing financial statements, assisting in the preparation of financing materials, and making management available for meetings and presentations.

Guarantee.reason: The Parent guarantees and stands surety for specific obligations related to D&O indemnification and insurance, as indicated in Section 5.7, which implies a limited guarantee.

Guarantee.answer: The guarantee becomes enforceable under conditions such as failure to perform provisions of the Agreement, breach of representations or covenants, and failure to pay a termination fee. This is implied by the sections discussing specific performance and termination, which indicate that breaches or failures to perform can lead to enforceable actions.
Guarantee.reason: The sections on specific performance and termination imply that breaches or failures to perform obligations under the Agreement trigger enforceability of the guarantee.
categories_used: Conditions to Closing  >  General and Mutual Conditions

Guarantee.answer: The Company agrees, on behalf of itself and its Affiliates, that none of the Financing Source Parties shall have any liability to the Company or its Affiliates (other than Parent and its Subsidiaries) relating to or arising out of this Agreement or the transactions contemplated by this Agreement, including the Financing, whether at law or equity, in contract, in tort or otherwise, and that neither the Company nor any of its Affiliates (other than Parent and its Subsidiaries) will have any rights or claims against any Financing Source Parties under this Agreement and any other agreement contemplated by, or entered into in connection with, the transactions contemplated by this Agreement, including any commitments by the Financing Source Parties in respect of the Financing.
Guarantee.reason: The clause explicitly states that the Financing Source Parties shall have no liability and that no claims can be brought against them, which is functionally equivalent to non-recourse language.

Guarantee.answer: The Target may enforce the guarantee through injunctive relief and specific performance, as the agreement explicitly states that the parties are entitled to an injunction or injunctions to prevent breaches and to enforce specifically the performance of the terms and provisions of the agreement. This is in addition to any other remedy to which they are entitled at law or in equity. The agreement also waives the requirement for the security or posting of any bond in connection with such remedies. There are no specific procedural steps or limitations mentioned beyond the general entitlement to these remedies.
Guarantee.reason: The agreement explicitly provides for injunctive relief and specific performance as remedies for breaches, indicating these are primary enforcement mechanisms for the guarantee.

The excerpts do not specify a survival period for the guarantee, and standard M&A language implies that unless explicitly stated, guarantees typically do not survive beyond the termination of the agreement.

The excerpts do not specify any limitations on who may enforce the guarantee or under what conditions, nor do they impose any specific requirements to pursue claims against the acquiror before the guarantor. The sections primarily discuss specific performance and waiver of claims against financing sources, which do not restrict enforcement of the guarantee.
categories_used: The Merger  >  Mechanics and Statutory Effects

Guarantee.answer: This Agreement limits enforcement rights by stating that it does not confer rights or remedies to any person other than the parties involved, with specific exceptions. The Company has the right to pursue damages on behalf of stockholders and award holders, but these individuals cannot bring actions themselves. Additionally, the Financing Source Parties are not liable to the Company or its affiliates, and claims against them must be brought in New York courts. Specific performance is available as a remedy, and jurisdiction is limited to Delaware courts, except for claims against Financing Source Parties, which are governed by New York law.
Guarantee.reason: The agreement explicitly outlines who can enforce rights and under what conditions, with specific carve-outs and jurisdictional limitations.

Guarantee.answer: Parent is responsible for ensuring that Merger Sub performs its obligations under the agreement and consummates the merger. This implies a broad guarantee of Merger Sub's obligations.
Guarantee.reason: The language in Section 5.11 indicates that Parent will take all necessary actions to cause Merger Sub to perform its obligations, which implies a broad guarantee of those obligations.

Guarantor.reason: The agreement implies that 'Parent' is responsible for causing its Subsidiaries to take actions, which suggests a guarantor role.

Law_and_Jurisdiction.answer: any state or Federal court sitting in the county of New York
Each party bears its own costs

No_Solicitation.reason: The agreement only allows the Target to consider unsolicited proposals under a fiduciary exception, with no explicit provision for a 'go-shop' period.

categories_used: Representations & Warranties  >  Recommendation of the Target Board

No_Solicitation.reason: The agreement provides the Buyer with a right to match or top a competing offer as indicated in Section 5.6(d), which allows the Company to negotiate with the Parent to modify the terms of the agreement so that a competing proposal is no longer a Superior Proposal.

No_Solicitation.answer: The Company must notify Parent in writing of its intention to effect an Adverse Recommendation Change or terminate the Agreement due to a Superior Proposal, providing a copy of the proposed definitive agreements and other transaction documentation. The Company must then negotiate in good faith with Parent for four business days to allow Parent to propose modifications to the Agreement. Any amendment to the financial terms or conditions of the Superior Proposal will restart the negotiation clock, requiring a new notice and a new negotiation period of two business days or the remainder of the original four-day period, whichever is longer.
No_Solicitation.reason: The procedural requirements are detailed in Section 5.6(d), which outlines the notice and negotiation obligations when the Company receives a Superior Proposal.

No_Solicitation.answer: There is no go-shop period mentioned. The agreement transitions directly to a no-shop provision, as the Company is restricted from soliciting or engaging in discussions for Acquisition Proposals from the date of the agreement. However, a fiduciary out clause allows the Company's board to consider superior proposals received after the no-shop begins, provided they were not solicited in violation of the agreement. This is permitted prior to obtaining the Company Stockholder Approval, and the Company must notify the Parent and allow for a negotiation period if it intends to change its recommendation or terminate the agreement for a superior proposal.
No_Solicitation.reason: The agreement specifies a no-shop provision with exceptions for unsolicited superior proposals, indicating a fiduciary out clause.

Ordinary_Course.answer: The Company shall, and shall cause its Subsidiaries to, use commercially reasonable efforts to conduct the business of the Company and its Subsidiaries in the ordinary course of business and, to the extent consistent therewith, use commercially reasonable efforts to (x) preserve its assets and business organization and maintain its existing relationships with material customers, suppliers, distributors, Governmental Authorities and business partners, and (y) keep available the services of key employees and comply in all material respects with applicable Law with respect to employee hiring practices and promotion practices.
Ordinary_Course.reason: The clause specifies the expectation for the Company to conduct business in the ordinary course, including preserving assets, maintaining relationships, and complying with laws, which implies the definition of 'ordinary course.'

categories_used: Conditions to Closing  >  General and Mutual Conditions
Conditions to Closing  >  General and Mutual Conditions
Conditions to Closing  >  General and Mutual Conditions

Ordinary_Course.answer: If the Company breaches its obligation to operate in the ordinary course, it could lead to a failure of a closing condition as outlined in Section 6.2(b), which requires the Company to have performed or complied in all material respects with its obligations under the Agreement. This breach could result in the Parent having the right to terminate the Agreement under Section 7.1(d)(i) if the breach is not curable or not cured within the specified time frame. Additionally, if the breach is knowing and intentional, it could result in liability for damages as per Section 7.2.
Ordinary_Course.reason: The breach of ordinary course obligations is linked to the failure of a closing condition in Section 6.2(b), and termination rights are specified in Section 7.1(d)(i). Liability for knowing and intentional breaches is addressed in Section 7.2.

Proxy_Statement.answer: The proxy is combined with a registration statement, specifically the S-4 Registration Statement.

Proxy_Statement.reason: The conditions to consummate the Merger include that the Form F-4 shall have become effective under the Securities Act and shall not be the subject of any stop order or proceedings by the SEC seeking a stop order, indicating SEC review clearance is required.
categories_used: Conditions to Closing  >  General and Mutual Conditions

Proxy_Statement.answer: within 50 days of the effectiveness of the Form F-4

R_W_Parent.answer: Each of Parent and each of the Merger Subs is a legal entity duly organized, validly existing and in good standing under the Laws of its respective jurisdiction of organization and has all requisite corporate or similar power and authority to own, lease and operate its properties and assets and to carry on its business as presently conducted and is qualified to do business and is in good standing as a foreign legal entity in each jurisdiction where the ownership, leasing or operation of its assets or properties or conduct of its business requires such qualification, except where the failure to be so organized, qualified or in good standing, or to have such power or authority, would not, individually or in the aggregate, reasonably be expected to have a Parent Material Adverse Effect.
categories_used: Conditions to Closing  >  General and Mutual Conditions

R_W_Parent.answer: Each of Parent and Merger Sub have all necessary organizational power and authority to execute, deliver and perform their respective obligations under this Agreement and to consummate the transactions contemplated by this Agreement.

Neither the execution and delivery of this Agreement by Parent and Merger Sub nor the consummation by Parent and Merger Sub of the transactions contemplated by this Agreement, nor compliance by Parent and Merger Sub with any of the applicable terms or provisions of this Agreement, will (i) violate any provision of the Parent Organizational Documents or the certificate of incorporation or bylaws (or equivalent organizational documents) of any Subsidiary of Parent, (ii) assuming that the Consents, registrations, declarations, filings and notices referenced in Section 4.5(b) have been obtained or made, conflict with or violate any Law applicable to Parent or any of its Subsidiaries or by which any property or asset of Parent or any of its Subsidiaries is bound or affected or (iii) violate, conflict with or result in any breach of any provision of, or loss of any benefit, or constitute a default (with or without notice or lapse of time, or both) under, give rise to any right of termination, acceleration or cancelation of or require the Consent of, notice to or filing with any third party pursuant to any of the terms or provisions of any Contract to which Parent or any of its Subsidiaries is a party or by which any property or asset of Parent or any of its Subsidiaries is bound or affected, or result in the creation of a Lien, other than any Permitted Lien, upon any of the property or assets of Parent or any of its Subsidiaries, other than, in the case of clause (i) with respect to the certificate of incorporation or bylaws (or equivalent organizational documents) of any Subsidiary of Parent (other than Merger Sub), clause (ii) and clause (iii), any such conflict, violation, breach, default, termination, acceleration, cancelation or Lien that (A) has not had, and would not reasonably be expected to have, individually or in the aggregate, a Material Adverse Effect on Parent and (B) would not reasonably be expected to, individually or in the aggregate, impair in any material respect the ability of Parent or Merger Sub to perform their respective obligations under this Agreement or to consummate the Merger, or prevent or materially delay the consummation of any of the Merger and the other transactions contemplated by this Agreement.

No Consent of, registration, declaration or filing with or notice to any Governmental Authority is required to be obtained or made by or with respect to Parent or any of its Subsidiaries in connection with the execution, delivery and performance of this Agreement or the consummation of the transactions contemplated by this Agreement, other than (i) applicable requirements of and filings with (x) the SEC under the Exchange Act or the Securities Act (including the filing with the SEC of the Form F-4 and the Proxy Statement), (y) the Registrar of Companies under the Companies Act 2014 of Ireland and (z) the ASIC, (ii) the filing of the Certificate of Merger with the Delaware Secretary of State, (iii) applicable requirements under non-United States qualification, state securities or 'blue sky' laws of various states or any applicable other securities Laws, (iv) compliance with applicable rules and regulations of ASX, the NYSE and any other applicable stock exchanges or marketplaces, (v) compliance with the Irish Companies Act 2014 (as amended), (vi) such other items required solely by reason of the participation and identity of the Company in the transactions contemplated by this Agreement, (vii) compliance with and filings or notifications under Antitrust Laws and (viii) such other Consents, registrations, declarations, filings or notices the failure of which to be obtained or made (A) has not had, and would not reasonably be expected to have, individually or in the aggregate, a Material Adverse Effect on Parent and (B) would not reasonably be expected to, individually or in the aggregate, impair in any material respect the ability of Parent or Merger Sub to perform its respective obligations under this Agreement or to consummate the Merger, or prevent or materially delay the consummation of any of the Merger and the other transactions contemplated by this Agreement.

Parent has filed all required SEC reports on a timely basis, and these reports comply in all material respects with applicable securities laws. The reports fairly present the financial condition of Parent and its subsidiaries in accordance with GAAP. Parent maintains disclosure controls and procedures, as well as internal control over financial reporting, to ensure the reliability of financial reporting and compliance with the Exchange Act and Sarbanes-Oxley Act.

As of the date of this Agreement, there is no Proceeding pending or, to the Knowledge of Parent, threatened against Parent or any of its Subsidiaries or any asset or property of Parent or any of its Subsidiaries, and neither Parent nor any of its Subsidiaries nor any asset or property of Parent or any of its Subsidiaries is subject to a continuing Order, in each case, that (a) has had, or would reasonably be expected to have, individually or in the aggregate, a Material Adverse Effect on Parent or (b) would reasonably be expected to, individually or in the aggregate, impair in any material respect the ability of Parent or Merger Sub to perform their respective obligations under this Agreement or to consummate the Merger, or prevent or materially delay the consummation of any of the Merger and the other transactions contemplated by this Agreement.

Parent and its Subsidiaries are in compliance in all material respects with applicable laws and regulations, except for violations that would not reasonably be expected to have a Parent Material Adverse Effect.
categories_used: Conditions to Closing  >  General and Mutual Conditions

R_W_Parent.answer: Parent has not employed any broker or finder or incurred any liability for any brokerage fees, commissions or finders' fees in connection with the Transactions, except that Parent has engaged J.P. Morgan Securities LLC and Guggenheim Securities, LLC as its financial advisors.

Parent represents that it has secured or arranged sufficient financing to complete the merger, as evidenced by the commitment letter and Debt Letters provided by the Initial Lenders, which are in full force and effect and sufficient to satisfy all obligations under the Agreement, including the payment of the Cash Consideration portion of the Merger Consideration and all fees and expenses.

All of the issued and outstanding Parent Shares have been, and all of the Parent Shares (or an applicable equivalent number of CUFS or ADSs evidenced by American Depository Receipts) that may be issued pursuant to the Parent Equity Awards, as amended from time to time, or other compensation plans of Parent will be, when issued in accordance with the respective terms thereof, duly authorized and validly issued, and, along with the Parent Shares issuable pursuant to this Agreement, are, or will be when issued, fully paid, nonassessable and free of preemptive rights.

Parent has engaged J.P. Morgan Securities LLC, Guggenheim Securities, LLC, Jefferies LLC, and BofA Securities, Inc. as financial advisors, and the fees and expenses will be paid by Parent or a controlled Affiliate of Parent.

R_W_Target.answer: Each of the Company and its Subsidiaries is a legal entity duly organized, validly existing and in good standing under the Laws of its respective jurisdiction of organization and has all requisite corporate or similar power and authority to own, lease and operate its properties and assets and to carry on its business as presently conducted and is qualified to do business and is in good standing as a foreign legal entity in each jurisdiction where the ownership, leasing or operation of its assets or properties or conduct of its business requires such qualification, except where the failure to be so organized, qualified or in good standing, or to have such power or authority, would not, individually or in the aggregate, reasonably be expected to have a Company Material Adverse Effect.

The Company has all necessary corporate power and authority to execute, deliver and perform its obligations under this Agreement and, subject to obtaining the Company Stockholder Approval, to consummate the transactions contemplated by this Agreement. The execution, delivery and performance of this Agreement by the Company have been duly and validly authorized by all necessary corporate action by the Company.
R_W_Target.reason: The statement in Section 3.3(a) of Article III explicitly confirms the Company's corporate authority to execute and perform its obligations under the agreement, subject to certain approvals.

R_W_Target.answer: The Company represents that neither the execution and delivery of the Agreement nor the consummation of the transactions contemplated by the Agreement will violate any provision of its Certificate of Incorporation or Bylaws, conflict with or violate any applicable Law, or result in a breach or default under any Contract, except where such conflict, violation, breach, or default would not reasonably be expected to have a Material Adverse Effect on the Company or impair its ability to perform its obligations under the Agreement.
R_W_Target.reason: The representation in Section 3.5(a) clearly outlines that the execution, delivery, and performance of the Agreement do not conflict with the Company's organizational documents, applicable laws, or contracts, except where such conflicts would not have a material adverse effect.
categories_used: Conditions to Closing  >  General and Mutual Conditions

R_W_Target.answer: The Target represents that the following consents or approvals are required to complete the merger: (a) Company Stockholder Approval, (b) approval for listing on the NYSE, (c) effectiveness of the Form F-4 under the Securities Act, (d) expiration or early termination of the waiting period under the HSR Act, (e) Governmental Consents of the FCC if required, and (f) other Governmental Consents set forth in the Company Disclosure Letter.
R_W_Target.reason: The conditions listed in the excerpts imply the necessary consents and approvals, including stockholder and regulatory approvals, as well as specific governmental consents related to antitrust and communications regulations.

R_W_Target.answer: Each of the Company and its Subsidiaries is a legal entity duly organized, validly existing, and in good standing under the laws of its respective jurisdiction of organization. The Company owns, directly or indirectly, all of the issued and outstanding ownership, voting, or similar interests in each of its Subsidiaries, free and clear of all Liens. All ownership interests of each Subsidiary are duly authorized, validly issued, fully paid, nonassessable, and free of preemptive rights.
R_W_Target.reason: The excerpts provide detailed information about the organization, existence, and ownership structure of the Company's subsidiaries, indicating that they are duly organized and owned by the Company.

R_W_Target.answer: As of the date of this Agreement, there is no Proceeding pending or, to the Knowledge of the Company, threatened against the Company or any of its Subsidiaries or any asset or property of the Company or any of its Subsidiaries, and neither the Company nor any of its Subsidiaries nor any asset or property of the Company or any of its Subsidiaries is subject to a continuing Order, in each case, that (a) has had, or would reasonably be expected to have, individually or in the aggregate, a Material Adverse Effect on the Company or (b) would reasonably be expected to, individually or in the aggregate, impair in any material respect the ability of the Company to perform its obligations under this Agreement or to consummate the Merger, or prevent or materially delay the consummation of any of the Merger and the other transactions contemplated by this Agreement.

The Company and its Subsidiaries own, validly license, or have the right to use all Intellectual Property rights used in their businesses. They are the exclusive owner of all Company Registered IP, which is subsisting, valid, and enforceable. There are no pending or threatened proceedings concerning the ownership, validity, or enforceability of any Company Owned IP. The Company has taken commercially reasonable measures to protect the confidentiality of all Trade Secrets, and there has been no unauthorized use or disclosure. Employees and consultants have agreements assigning IP to the Company. The Company's business does not infringe on others' IP rights, and no claims of infringement are pending or threatened against the Company.
R_W_Target.reason: The document provides detailed representations and warranties regarding the ownership, validity, and protection of the Company's Intellectual Property, as well as the absence of infringement claims.

R_W_Target.answer: Each Company Material Contract is a valid and binding obligation of the Company or its Subsidiary that is a party thereto, and to the Knowledge of the Company, the other parties thereto, and is in full force and effect, except for potential limitations due to bankruptcy or similar laws and equitable defenses.

The Company represents that it is in compliance with applicable laws and possesses necessary permits, except for violations that would not reasonably be expected to have a material adverse effect. This includes compliance with environmental laws, anti-corruption laws, and possession of necessary licenses and permits.
R_W_Target.reason: The Company has made representations of compliance with various laws and possession of necessary permits, qualified by materiality, which is a standard representation in M&A agreements.
categories_used: Conditions to Closing  >  General and Mutual Conditions

R_W_Target.answer: The Company is in compliance with employee-related matters, including the establishment, maintenance, and administration of benefit plans in accordance with applicable laws such as ERISA and the Code. There are no pending or threatened material labor disputes, strikes, or union activities affecting the Company. The Company is not bound by any labor agreements, and there are no ongoing labor union organizing activities. The Company and its Subsidiaries are in compliance with labor and employment laws covering wages, hours, workplace safety, anti-discrimination, and similar matters, except where failure to comply would not be materially adverse. The Company has no obligations for post-termination health, welfare, or life insurance benefits under any Company Benefit Plan, except as required by law.
categories_used: The Merger  >  Post-Closing Board and Management

R_W_Target.answer: Except as has not had, and would not reasonably be expected to have, individually or in the aggregate, a Material Adverse Effect on the Company, the Company and each of its Subsidiaries have (i) timely filed or caused to be timely filed (taking into account any extension of time within which to file) all Tax Returns required to be filed by any of them, and all such filed Tax Returns (taking into account all amendments thereto) are true, complete and accurate and (ii) paid (or have had paid on their behalf) all Taxes due and owing, except, in the case of clause (ii) hereof, with respect to Taxes contested in good faith by appropriate Proceedings or for which adequate reserves or accruals have been established (as of the date of this Agreement and as of the Closing) in accordance with GAAP.
R_W_Target.reason: The language explicitly states that all required Tax Returns have been filed and Taxes paid, with exceptions for contested taxes or those with adequate reserves, indicating compliance with tax laws and absence of material outstanding liabilities.
categories_used: Financing Provisions  >  Tax Treatment of Transaction

R_W_Target.answer: The Target will owe brokerage, finders, or advisory fees to Goldman Sachs & Co. LLC and Centerview Partners LLC.

Except for liabilities or obligations (a) as (and to the extent) reflected, disclosed or reserved against in the Company's balance sheets (or the notes thereto) included in the Company's Annual Report on Form 10-K filed with the SEC on November 20, 2024, or the Company's Quarterly Report on Form 10-Q filed with the SEC on February 5, 2025, (b) incurred in the ordinary course of business since September 30, 2024, (c) incurred in connection with the transactions contemplated by this Agreement or (d) that have not had, and would not reasonably be expected to have, individually or in the aggregate, a Material Adverse Effect on the Company, none of the Company or any of its Subsidiaries has any liabilities or obligations of any nature, whether or not accrued, contingent, absolute or otherwise and whether or not required to be reflected on a consolidated balance sheet of the Company (or the notes thereto) in accordance with GAAP.

Regulatory_Approvals.answer: Each of the parties hereto shall, in consultation and cooperation with the other parties and as promptly as reasonably practicable, but in any event no later than twenty-five (25) Business Days following the date of this Agreement, make its respective filings under the HSR Act, and make any other applications and filings as reasonably determined by the Company and Parent under other applicable Antitrust Laws with respect to the transactions contemplated by this Agreement, as promptly as practicable, but in no event later than as required by Law.
categories_used: Conditions to Closing  >  General and Mutual Conditions

Regulatory_Approvals.reason: The document states that Parent, Merger Sub, and Parent's Subsidiaries shall take all actions necessary to eliminate impediments under any Antitrust Law, including agreeing to divestitures or other Remedy Actions, indicating a divestiture or remedy obligation.
categories_used: Conditions to Closing  >  General and Mutual Conditions

Regulatory_Approvals.answer: Parent and its Subsidiaries shall not be required to agree to, commit to, proffer, propose or take any Remedy Actions with respect to any businesses and products of the Company and its Subsidiaries that individually or in the aggregate, generated net sales in excess of $140,000,000 during the Company's 2024 fiscal year.

Regulatory_Approvals.reason: The document specifies that if the agreement is terminated due to regulatory failure, the Parent must pay the Parent Regulatory Termination Fee, indicating a reverse termination fee is due upon failure to obtain regulatory approvals.
categories_used: Conditions to Closing  >  General and Mutual Conditions

Regulatory_Approvals.answer: The Company and Parent are obligated to cooperate and use their reasonable best efforts to obtain necessary regulatory approvals, including sharing information, coordinating responses, and jointly defending litigation. They must consult and cooperate with each other on filings and communications with Governmental Entities, and coordinate on antitrust and communications laws. They must also notify each other of any filings or communications with Governmental Entities and provide opportunities for review and comment. In case of disputes, the general counsels of both parties will resolve them, with Parent having the final determination if unresolved.
Regulatory_Approvals.reason: The document outlines specific obligations for cooperation, information sharing, and joint defense in regulatory matters, indicating a clear summary of regulatory cooperation covenants.

Termination.answer: Either party has the right to terminate the agreement due to a material breach by the other party, as implied by Section 7.1(c)(i) and Section 7.1(d)(i), which allow termination if a breach is not capable of being cured or is not cured within a specified period.
Termination.reason: The agreement provides specific conditions under which either party can terminate due to a breach, including cure periods, which implies the right to terminate for material breaches.

The agreement allows termination if closing conditions are not satisfied, as indicated by provisions allowing termination if the merger is not consummated by the Termination Date due to unsatisfied conditions, such as regulatory approvals or shareholder approvals.
categories_used: Conditions to Closing  >  General and Mutual Conditions
Conditions to Closing  >  General and Mutual Conditions

Termination.reason: The Company Termination Fee is explicitly stated as $1,525,000,000 in Section 7.05(b) for specific termination scenarios involving a Company Change in Recommendation or a Superior Company Proposal.

The agreement specifies a 'Parent Regulatory Termination Fee' of $2,500,000,000 payable by the Parent under certain termination conditions related to regulatory issues, which is functionally equivalent to a reverse termination fee.

Termination.answer: Termination notice must be provided in writing and can be delivered by hand, prepaid overnight courier with proof of delivery, or confirmed electronic mail. Notices are deemed given upon receipt, except for electronic mail received after 7:00 p.m. local time or on non-business days, which are deemed received at 9:00 a.m. on the next business day.
Termination.reason: The general notice provisions specify the acceptable forms and timing for delivering notices, which can be reasonably inferred to apply to termination notices as well.

Termination.answer: Section 5.07(b) (Access, Consultation), Section 5.11 (Expenses), Section 5.16(h) (Company Financing Indemnification), Section 5.16(j) (Parent Financing Indemnification), Section 7.05 (Effect of Termination and Abandonment), the indemnification obligation set forth in Section 5.22(f) (Hook Stock) and the Confidentiality Agreement

Written notice is required when exercising termination rights, specifying the provisions under which termination is made. Notices must be in writing and can be delivered by hand, overnight courier, or confirmed electronic mail.
Termination.reason: The agreement specifies that written notice must be given by the terminating party to the other party, detailing the provisions for termination. General notice provisions in Section 8.4 outline acceptable delivery methods.

Termination.answer: The agreement includes unique termination rights such as the ability for the Company to terminate the agreement prior to the Company Stockholder Approval to enter into a definitive agreement with respect to a Superior Proposal, provided certain conditions are met, including the payment of the Termination Amount. Additionally, Parent can terminate the agreement if the Company Board makes an Adverse Recommendation Change or fails to reaffirm the Company Recommendation under certain conditions. These scenarios are nonstandard as they allow termination based on changes in recommendation or pursuit of superior proposals.
Termination.reason: The agreement specifies termination rights related to changes in recommendation and superior proposals, which are not standard termination scenarios like breach or regulatory issues.

Termination.answer: The termination fee payable by the Company is $1,525,000,000, referred to as the 'Company Termination Fee'. Additionally, the Company may be required to pay a 'Termination Amount' of $272,000,000 under certain conditions. The Parent may also be required to pay a termination fee of $1,525,000,000, referred to as the 'Parent Termination Fee', or a 'Parent Regulatory Termination Fee' of $2,500,000,000 under specific circumstances.

Parent is obligated to pay a Parent Regulatory Termination Fee of $2,500,000,000 if the agreement is terminated due to regulatory issues, such as failure to obtain antitrust clearance or other governmental approvals.
Termination.reason: Section 7.05(c) specifies that if the agreement is terminated due to regulatory issues, Parent must pay a Parent Regulatory Termination Fee, which implies a reverse termination fee for regulatory failures.

answer: Acceptance of a superior proposal by the Company prior to obtaining stockholder approval, leading to termination of the agreement (Section 7.1(c)(ii)).
Material breach of covenants or agreements by the Company, resulting in termination by Parent (Section 7.1(d)(i)).
Failure to obtain required stockholder approvals, resulting in termination by either party (Section 7.1(b)(iii)).
Board withdrawal or adverse change of recommendation by the Company Board, leading to termination by Parent (Section 7.1(d)(ii)).
Failure to consummate the transaction by the termination date due to specified reasons, such as not obtaining required governmental consents (Section 7.1(b)(i)).

Termination.answer: If the Agreement is terminated by the Company pursuant to Section 7.03(b) (Parent Breach) in respect of any covenant of Parent or a Merger Sub, and prior to such termination, a bona fide Parent Acquisition Proposal has been made, and within 12 months after such termination, Parent consummates a Parent Acquisition Proposal or enters into an agreement contemplating a Parent Acquisition Proposal, then Parent shall pay the Parent Termination Fee. Additionally, if the Agreement is terminated by the Company or Parent pursuant to Section 7.02(d) (Law; Final and Non-Appealable Order) as the result of any applicable Antitrust Law, Communications Law or Foreign Regulatory Law, and all other conditions have been satisfied or waived, then Parent shall pay the Parent Regulatory Termination Fee.
Termination.reason: The conditions for the Parent to pay a termination fee are outlined in Section 7.05(c), which includes breaches by Parent or regulatory failures, implying reverse termination fee triggers.

Termination.answer: In the case of clause (i), on the same day as the earlier of any consummation of, or entry into a definitive agreement with respect to, the transaction contemplated therein; in the case of clause (ii), immediately prior to or substantially concurrently with such termination; and in the case of clause (iii), promptly, but in no event later than two (2) Business Days after the date of such termination.

Termination_Fees__Parent_to_Target_.reason: The timing for payment of the Termination Amount is specified in Section 7.3(a) as follows: (A) on the same day as the earlier of any consummation of, or entry into a definitive agreement with respect to, the transaction contemplated therein, (B) immediately prior to or substantially concurrently with such termination, and (C) promptly, but in no event later than two (2) Business Days after the date of such termination.
